quoteFirst: _If the minority of the people of America refuse to coalesce with the majority on just and proper principles; if a separation must take place, it could never happen on better grounds._ The votes of yesterday against the just principle of representation were as
quoteLast: ty of the people of America. Taking the opinions to be the same on this point, and he was sure, if there was any room for change, it could not be on the side of the majority, the question will be, shall less than one-fourth of the United States withdraw themselves from the Union, or shall more than three-fourths renounce the inherent, indisputable and unalienable rights of men, in favor of the artificial system of States? If issue must be joined, it was on this point he would choose to join it.
title: A Source Book in American History to 1787
author: West, Willis M. (Willis Mason), 1857-1931 [Editor]

title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: The _Calliope_ was hit several times but did not sustain serious damage, although, I regret to say, she had several casualties. The light cruisers attacked the enemy’s battleships with torpedoes at this time, but were not able to observe the result; an explosion on board a ship of the “Kaiser” class was seen, however, at
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: [M] The ships sighted turned away and touch could not be regained, although sounds of gunfire could be heard from ahead at 8.25 P.M., probably from our battle cruisers, which obtained touch with and engaged some of the enemy’s ships very effectively between 8.22 and 8.25 P.M. The _Falmouth_ was the last ship of the Battle Cruiser Fleet to be in touch with the enemy, at
quoteLast: ; the ships then in sight turned eight points together away from the _Falmouth_.
title: The Grand Fleet, 1914-1916
author: Jellicoe, John Rushworth, 1859-1935

quoteFirst: It will thus be perceived that the portion of Beacon Hill, included between Beacon Street, Beaver Street, Cambridge Street, Bowdoin Square, Court Street, Tremont Row, and Tremont Street, containing about seventy-three acres, was sold, less than a century ago, at prices ranging from
quoteLast: hundred dollars per acre, aggregating less than thirty thousand dollars. It now comprises the ninth ward of the city of Boston, and contains within its limits a real estate valuation of sixteen millions of dollars.
title: The Bay State Monthly — Volume 1, No. 6, June, 1884
author: Various

title: The Three Voyages of Captain Cook Round the World. Vol. VI. Being the Second of the Third Voyage

quoteFirst: _Indomitable_ and _New Zealand_ engaged a third and sent her out of the line, heeling over and burning also. Then the mist came down once more and the enemy was last seen by _Falmouth_ at
title: The British Navy in Battle
author: Pollen, Arthur Joseph Hungerford, 1866-1937

quoteFirst: There were in the late summer of 1848, in the Schools of the Royal Academy or barely emergent from them, four young men to whom this condition of the art seemed offensive, contemptible, and even scandalous. Their names were William Holman-Hunt, John Everett Millais, and Dante Gabriel Rossetti, painters, and Thomas Woolner, sculptor. Their ages varied from
quoteLast: teen--Woolner being the eldest, and Millais the youngest. Being little more than lads, these young men were naturally not very deep in either the theory or the practice of art: but they had open eyes and minds, and could discern that some things were good and other bad--that some things they liked, and others they hated.
title: The Germ: Thoughts towards Nature in Poetry, Literature and Art
author: Various; Rossetti, William Michael, 1829-1919 [Commentator]; Rossetti, Dante Gabriel, 1828-1882 [Editor]
